article.paragraph: Croatia(IPAc-enen-us-Croatia.oggkroʊˈeɪʃərespellkrohAYshə;lang-hrHrvatskaIPA-shxř̩ʋaːtskaː), officially theRepublic of Croatia(lang-hrRepublika Hrvatskano,AudioRepublika_Hrvatska.ogglisten), is asovereign stateat the crossroads ofCentral Europe,Southeast Europe, and theMediterranean SeaMediterranean. Itscapital cityisZagreb, which forms one of the country'sadministrative divisions of Croatiaprimary subdivisions, along with itsCounties of Croatiatwenty counties. Croatia coversconvert56594km2sqmi0offand has diverse, mostlyContinental climatecontinentalandMediterranean climates. Croatia'sAdriatic Seacoast containsList of islands of Croatiamore than a thousand islands. The country's population is 4.28 million, most of whom areCroats, with the most common religious denomination beingCatholic ChurchRoman Catholicism.

The Croats arrived in the area of present-day Croatia during the early part of the 7th century AD. They organised the state into two duchies by the 9th century.Tomislav of CroatiaTomislavbecame the first king by 925, elevating Croatia to the status of a kingdom. TheKingdom of Croatia (9251102)Kingdom of Croatiaretained its sovereignty for nearly two centuries, reaching its peak during the rule ofKings of CroatiaKingsPeter Kreimir IV of CroatiaPeter Kreimir IVandDemetrius Zvonimir of CroatiaDmitar Zvonimir. Croatia entered aCroatia in the union with Hungarypersonal unionwithKingdom of HungaryHungaryin 1102. In 1527, faced withHundred Years' CroatianOttoman WarOttoman conquest, the1527 election in CetinCroatian Parliament electedFerdinand I, Holy Roman EmperorFerdinand Iof theHouse of Habsburgto the Croatian throne. In 1918, afterWorld War I, Croatia was included in the unrecognisedState of Slovenes, Croats and Serbswhich seceded fromAustria-HungaryandCreation of Yugoslaviamerged intotheKingdom of Yugoslavia. AIndependent State of Croatiafascist Croatian puppet stateexisted duringWorld War II. After the war, Croatia became a founding member and a federal constituent ofSocialist Federal Republic of YugoslaviaSecond Yugoslavia, a constitutionallysocialist state. In June 1991, CroatiaIndependence of Croatiadeclared independence, which came into effect on 8 October of the same year. TheCroatian War of Independencewas fought successfully during the four years following the declaration.

Aunitary state, Croatia is arepublicgoverned under aparliamentary system. TheInternational Monetary Fundclassified Croatia as an emerging and developing economy, and theWorld Bankidentified it as aWorld Bank high-income economyhigh-income economy. Croatia is a member of theEuropean Union(EU),United Nations(UN), theCouncil of Europe,NATO, theWorld Trade Organization(WTO) and a founding member of theUnion for the Mediterranean. As an active participant in theUnited Nations peacekeepingUN peacekeeping forces, Croatia has contributed troops to theInternational Security Assistance ForceNATO-led mission in Afghanistanand took a non-permanent seat on theUnited Nations Security CouncilUN Security Councilfor the 20082009 term.

Theservice sectordominates Croatia's economy, followed by theindustrial sectorandagriculture.Tourism in CroatiaTourismis a significant source of revenue during the summer, with Croatia ranked the 18th most popular tourist destination in the world. The state controls a part of the economy, with substantial government expenditure. The European Union is Croatia's most importantinternational tradetrading partner. Since 2000, the Croatian government has invested in infrastructure, especiallyTransport in Croatiatransport routes and facilitiesalong thePan-European corridors. Internal sources produce a significant portion ofenergy in Croatia; the rest is imported. Croatia provides auniversal health caresystem and freeEducation in Croatiaprimary and secondary education, while supportingCulture of Croatiaculturethrough numerous public institutions and through corporate investments inMedia of CroatiamediaandCroatian literaturepublishing.

The origin of the name is uncertain, but is thought to be aGothic languageGothicorIndo-Aryan languagesIndo-Aryanterm assigned to aSlavic peoplesSlavic tribe.cite web[[University of Kansas]]Marc L. GreenbergThe Role of Language in the Creation of Identity: Myths in Linguistics among the Peoples of the Former Yugoslaviahttp://kuscholarworks.ku.edu/dspace/bitstream/1808/969/1/yugoslav_myths96.pdfPDFApril 199614 October 2011The oldest preserved record of the Croatianethnonym*xrvat is of variable stem, attested in theBaka tabletinStyle (manner of address)stylezvnmir kral xrvatsk("Dmitar ZvonimirZvonimir, Croatian king").cite journalhttp://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?showBrankoFučićBranko FučićNajstariji hrvatski glagoljski natpisiThe Oldest Croatian Glagolitic Inscriptions[[Slovo (journal)|Slovo]][[Old Church Slavonic Institute]]21September 1971Croatian227–25414 October 2011

The first attestation of the Latin term is attributed to a charter of DukeTrpimir I of CroatiaTrpimirfrom the year 852. The original is lost, and just a 1568 copy is preservedleading to doubts over the authenticity of the claim.Mui (2007), p. 27The oldest preserved stone inscription is the 9th-century Branimir Inscription (found nearBenkovac), where DukeBranimir of CroatiaBranimiris styled asDux Cruatorvm. Theinscriptionis not believed to be dated accurately, but is likely to be from during the period of 879-892, during Branimir's rule.Mui (2007), pp. 195198

article.heading: Greek and Roman rule
article.paragraph: Much later, the region was settled byLiburniansandIllyrians, while the firstGreeceGreekcolonies were established on the islands ofKorula,Hvarcite bookhttps://books.google.com/books/about/The_Illyrians.html?idJohn WilkesThe Illyrians1995[[Wiley-Blackwell]]Oxford, UK978-0-631-19807-9114... in the early history of the colony settled in 385 BC on the island Pharos (Hvar) from the Aegean island Paros, famed for its marble. In traditional fashion they accepted the guidance of an oracle, ...15 October 2011andVis (island)Vis.cite bookhttp://www.scribd.com/doc/15826619/John-Wilkes-The-IllyriansJohn WilkesThe Illyrians1995[[Wiley-Blackwell]]Oxford, UK978-0-631-19807-9115The third Greek colony known in this central sector of the Dalmatian coast was Issa, on the north side of the island Vis.3 April 2012In 9 AD the territory of today's Croatia became part of theRoman Empire. EmperorDiocletianbuilt aDiocletian's Palacelarge palaceinSplit, CroatiaSplitwhen he retired in AD 305.cite book[[Edward Gibbon]][[John Bagnell Bury]][[Daniel J. Boorstin]]The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire[[Modern Library]]1995New York335978-0-679-60148-7https://books.google.com/books?id27 October 2011

During the 5th century, one of theConcise list of Roman emperors#Western Roman Empirelast Emperors of the Western Roman Empire,Julius Nepos, ruled his small empire from the palace.cite bookhttps://books.google.com/books?id[[J. B. Bury]]History of the later Roman empire from the death of Theodosius I. to the death of Justinian408[[Macmillan Publishers]]192315 October 2011The period ends withAvars (Carpathians)AvarandCroatsCroatinvasions in the first half of the 7th century and destruction of almost all Roman towns. Roman survivors retreated to more favourable sites on the coast, islands and mountains. The city ofDubrovnikwas founded by such survivors fromEpidaurum.cite bookhttps://books.google.com/books?idResearches on the Danube and the AdriaticAndrew Archibald Paton1861218–219Trübner15 October 2011

Theethnogenesisof Croats is uncertain and there are several competing theories,SlavicandIranianbeing the most frequently put forward. The most widely accepted of these, theSlavictheory, proposes migration ofWhite Croatsfrom the territory ofWhite Croatiaduring theMigration Period. Conversely, theIraniantheory proposesIranian peoplesIranianorigin, based onTanais TabletscontainingGreek languageGreekinscription of given names[],and(Khoroathos, Khorothos, and Khorathos) and their interpretation asanthroponymsof Croatian people.cite journalMigracijske i etničke teme1333-2546Institute for Migration and Ethnic StudiesSeptember 2007233251–268Emil HeršakBoris NikšićCroatianHrvatska etnogeneza: pregled komponentnih etapa i interpretacija (s naglaskom na euroazijske/nomadske sadržaje)Croatian Ethnogenesis: A Review of Component Stages and Interpretations (with Emphasis on Eurasian/Nomadic Elements)http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show
article.heading: Middle Ages
article.paragraph: MainDuchy of CroatiaKingdom of Croatia (925–1102)Kingdom of Croatia (1102–1526)Republic of RagusaFile:Bascanska ploca.jpgthumbBaka tablet, the oldest evidence of theGlagolitic alphabetglagolitic scriptAccording to the workDe Administrando Imperiowritten by the 10th-century Byzantine EmperorConstantine VII, the Croats had arrived in what is today Croatia in the early 7th century, however that claim is disputed and competing hypotheses date the event between the 6th and the 9th centuries.Mui (2007), pp. 249293Eventually twodukedom (administrative division)dukedomswere formedPannonian CroatiaDuchy of PannoniaandDuchy of Croatia, ruled byLjudevit PosavskiandBorna of CroatiaBorna, as attested by chronicles ofEinhardstarting in 818. The record represents the first document of Croatian realms,vassal statesofFranciaat the time.Mui (2007), pp. 157160

The Frankish overlordship ended during the reign ofMislav of CroatiaMislavtwo decades later.Mui (2007), pp. 169170According to the Constantine VIIChristianizationof Croats began in the 7th century, but the claim is disputed and generally Christianization is associated with the 9th century.cite journalBogoslovska smotraUniversity of Zagreb, Catholic Faculty of Theology0352-3101April 19683–437Antun IvandijaPokrštenje Hrvata prema najnovijim znanstvenim rezultatimaChristianization of Croats according to the most recent scientific resultsCroatian440–444http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?showThe first native Croatian ruler recognised by thePopewas Duke Branimir, who received papal recognition fromPope John VIIIin 7 June 879.

File:Dubrovnik wall.jpgthumbThewalls of Dubrovnikhelped to defend the city sinceMiddle Agesuntil theSiege of Dubrovnik19911992 siege.Tomislav of CroatiaTomislavwas the first ruler of Croatia who was styled a king in a letter from thePope John X, dating kingdom of Croatia to year 925. Tomislav defeated Hungarian andCroatianBulgarian battle of 926Bulgarian invasions, spreading the influence of Croatian kings.cite journalRadovi Zavoda za hrvatsku povijest3010353-295X281–290Povijesni zemljovidi i granice Hrvatske u Tomislavovo dobaHistorical maps and borders of Croatia in age of TomislavCroatianVladimir PosavecMarch 199816 October 2011http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?showThe medieval Croatian kingdom reached its peak in the 11th century during the reigns ofPetar Kreimir IV of CroatiaPetar Kreimir IV(10581074) andDemetrius Zvonimir of CroatiaDmitar Zvonimir(10751089).cite journalRadovi Zavoda za hrvatsku povijest2910353-295X11–20Regnum Croatiae et Dalmatiae u doba Stjepana II.Regnum Croatiae et Dalmatiae in age of Stjepan IICroatianLujo MargetićJanuary 199716 October 2011http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?showWhenStephen II of CroatiaStjepan IIdied in 1091 ending theHouse of TrpimiroviTrpimirovidynasty,Ladislaus I of Hungaryclaimed Croatian crown. Opposition to the claim led to aBattle of Gvozd MountainwarandCroatia in personal union with Hungarypersonal union of Croatia and Hungaryin 1102, ruled byColoman, King of HungaryColoman.cite journalScrinia Slavonica1332-4853Hrvatski institut za povijest – Podružnica za povijest Slavonije, Srijema i BaranjeHrvatsko-ugarski odnosi od sredinjega vijeka do nagodbe iz 1868. s posebnim osvrtom na pitanja SlavonijeCroatian-Hungarian relations from the Middle Ages to the Compromise of 1868, with a special survey of the Slavonian issueCroatianhttp://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?showLadislav HekaOctober 200881152–17316 October 2011

For the next four centuries, the Kingdom of Croatia was ruled by theSabor(parliament) and aBan of CroatiaBan(viceroy) appointed by the king.cite webhttp://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?secPovijest saborovanjaHistory of parliamentarismCroatian[[Sabor]]18 October 201026 July 2012nohttp://www.webcitation.org/69Qkc8832The period saw increasing threat ofOttoman EmpireOttomanconquest and struggle against theRepublic of Venicefor control of coastal areas. The Venetians gained control over most of Dalmatia by 1428, with exception of theRepublic of Ragusacity-state of Dubrovnikwhich became independent.Hundred Years' CroatianOttoman WarOttoman conquestsled to the 1493Battle of Krbava fieldand 1526Battle of Mohcs, both ending in decisive Ottoman victories. KingLouis II of HungaryLouis IIdied at Mohcs, and in 1527, the Croatian Parliament1527 election in Cetinmet in Cetin and choseFerdinand I, Holy Roman EmperorFerdinand Iof theHouse of Habsburgas new ruler of Croatia, under the condition that he provide protection to Croatia against the Ottoman Empire while respecting its political rights.Frucht 2005, p. 422423This period saw the rise of influential nobility such as theFrankopanandZrinskifamilies to prominence and ultimately numerous Bans from the two families.cite journalPovijesni prilozihttp://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show0351-9767Croatian Institute of HistoryJuly 200528287–22Márta FontUgarsko Kraljevstvo i Hrvatska u srednjem vijekuCroatianHungarian Kingdom and Croatia in the Middlea Ages17 October 2011
article.heading: Habsburg Monarchy and Austria-Hungary (15381918)
article.paragraph: MainKingdom of Croatia (Habsburg)Croatian–Ottoman WarsAustria-HungaryFile:Trogir3.jpgthumbView ofTrogir. From 1420 to 1797 theRepublic of Venicecontrolled most ofVenetian DalmatiaDalmatia.Following the decisive Ottoman victories, Croatia was split into civilian and military territories, with the partition formed in 1538. The military territories would become known as theCroatian Military Frontierand were under direct Imperial control.Hundred Years' CroatianOttoman WarOttoman advancesin the Croatian territory continued until the 1593Battle of Sisak, the first decisive Ottoman defeat, and stabilisation of borders.

During theGreat Turkish War(16671698),Slavoniawas regained but westernBosnia, which had been part of Croatia before the Ottoman conquest, remained outside Croatian control.The present-day border between the two countries is a remnant of this outcome.Dalmatia, the southern part of the border, was similarly defined by theCretan War (16451669)Fifthand theOttomanVenetian War (17141718)Seventh OttomanVenetian Wars.Lane (1973), p. 409

TheCroatianOttoman WarsOttoman warsinstigated great demographic changes. Croats migrated towardsAustriaand the present-dayBurgenland Croatsare direct descendants of these settlers.cite webCroatian Cultural Association in Burgenlandhttp://www.hkd.at/index.php?optionCroatianPovijest Gradišćanskih HrvatovHistory of Burgenland Croats17 October 201126 July 2012nohttp://www.webcitation.org/69Qku2uNTTo replace the fleeing population, the Habsburgs encouraged theChristianpopulations of Bosnia andSerbiato provide military service in the Croatian Military Frontier. Serb migration into this region peaked during theGreat Serb Migrationsof 1690 and 173739.cite book[[John R. Lampe]]Marvin R. JacksonBalkan economic history, 1550–1950: from imperial borderlands to developing nations62[[Indiana University Press]]1982978-0-253-30368-4https://books.google.com/books?id17 October 2011File:Johann Peter Krafft 005.jpgthumbrightCroatian ''Ban of Croatiaban''Nikola ubi Zrinskiis honored as a national hero both in Croatia and in Hungary for his defense ofSiege of SzigetvrSzigetvragainst theOttoman wars in Europeinvading Ottoman Turks.

Between 1797 and 1809 theFirst French Empiregradually occupied the entire easternAdriaticcoastline and a substantial part of its hinterland, ending theRepublic of VeniceVenetianand theRepublic of RagusaRagusanrepublics, establishing theIllyrian Provinces.In response theRoyal Navystarted theAdriatic campaign of 18071814blockade of the Adriatic Sealeading to theBattle of Lissa (1811)Battle of Visin 1811.Adkins, pp. 359362The Illyrian Provinces were captured by the Austrians in 1813, and absorbed by theAustrian Empirefollowing theCongress of Viennain 1815. This led to formation of theKingdom of Dalmatiaand restoration of theCroatian Littoralto the Kingdom of Croatia, now both under the same crown.cite bookhttps://books.google.com/books?id[[Harold Nicolson]]The Congress of Vienna: A Study in Allied Unity: 1812–1822[[Grove Press]]978-0-8021-3744-9180200017 October 2011

The 1830s and 1840s sawromantic nationalisminspire theIllyrian movementCroatian National Revival, a political and cultural campaign advocating the unity of allSouth Slavsin the empire. Its primary focus was the establishment of a standard language as a counterweight toHungarian languageHungarian, along with the promotion of Croatian literature and culture.cite journalCris: časopis Povijesnog društva Križevci1332-2567http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?showNikša StančićHrvatski narodni preporod – ciljevi i ostvarenjaCroatian National Revival – goals and achievements6–17101February 20097 October 2011CroatianDuring theHungarian Revolution of 1848Croatia sided with the Austrians, BanJosip Jelaihelping defeat the Hungarian forces in 1849, and ushering a period ofGermanizationpolicy.cite journalReview of Croatian HistoryCroatian Institute of History1845-438041December 2008Ante ČuvaloJosip Jelačić – Ban of Croatia13–27http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show17 October 2011

By the 1860s, failure of the policy became apparent, leading to theAustro-Hungarian Compromise of 1867and creation of apersonal unionbetween the crowns of theAustrian Empireand theKingdom of Hungary. The treaty left the issue of Croatia's status to Hungary, and the status was resolved by theCroatianHungarian Settlementof 1868, when kingdoms of Croatia and Slavonia were united.cite webhttp://www.h-net.org/~habsweb/sourcetexts/nagodba1.htmConstitution of Union between Croatia-Slavonia and HungaryH-net.org16 May 2010The Kingdom of Dalmatia remained under de facto Austrian control, whileRijekaretained the status ofCorpus separatum (Fiume)Corpus separatumintroduced in 1779.File:Ivan Zasche, Portret bana Josipa Jelacica.jpgthumbuprightBanJosip JelaifoughtHungarian Revolution of 1848Hungarians in 1848 and 1849.AfterAustria-Hungaryoccupied Bosnia and Herzegovina following theTreaty of Berlin (1878)1878 Treaty of Berlin, the Croatian Military Frontier was abolished and the territory returned to Croatia in 1881,pursuant to provisions of the Croatian-Hungarian settlement.cite journalZbornik Pravnog fakulteta Sveučilišta u Rijeci1330-349X[[University of Rijeka]]http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?showLadislav HekaHrvatsko-ugarska nagodba u zrcalu tiskaCroatianCroatian-Hungarian compromise in light of press clips282December 200710 April 2012931–971cite journalPolitička misao0032-3241[[University of Zagreb]], Faculty of Political SciencesPolitičko-teritorijalna podjela i opseg civilne Hrvatske u godinama sjedinjenja s vojnom Hrvatskom 1871–1886Political and territorial division and scope of civilian Croatia in the period of unification with the Croatian military frontier 1871–1886Croatianhttp://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?showBranko Dubravica159–172383January 200220 June 2012Renewed efforts toUnited States of Greater Austriareform Austria-Hungary, entailingfederalisationwith Croatia as a federal unit, were stopped by advent ofWorld War I.cite bookMax PolatschekFranz Ferdinand: Europas verlorene HoffnungGerman978-3-85002-284-2Amalthea198923117 October 2011https://books.google.com/books?id
article.heading: Yugoslavia (19181991)
article.paragraph: MainCreation of YugoslaviaKingdom of YugoslaviaBanovina of CroatiaWorld War II in YugoslaviaIndependent State of CroatiaSocialist Republic of CroatiaOn 29 October 1918 the Croatian Sabor declared independence and decided to join the newly formedState of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs,which in turn entered into union with theKingdom of Serbiaon 4 December 1918 to form theKingdom of Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes.cite bookWorld War I: encyclopedia, Volume 1Spencer TuckerPriscilla Mary Roberts978-1-85109-420-212862005ABC-CLIO27 October 2011https://books.google.com/books?idTheVidovdan Constitution1921 constitutiondefining the country as aunitary stateand abolition of historical administrative divisions effectively ended Croatian autonomy. The new constitution was opposed by the most widely supported national political partytheCroatian Peasant Party(HSS) led byStjepan Radi.cite journalScrinia SlavonicaCroatian Institute of History – Slavonia, Syrmium and Baranya history branch1332-4853http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show31November 2003Parlamentarni izbori u Brodskom kotaru 1923. godineCroatianParliamentary Elections in the Brod District in 193217 October 2011452–470File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-2000-0518-506, Stephan Radic.jpgthumbuprightStjepan Radi, a founder of the HSS, who opposed the creation of YugoslaviaThe political situation deteriorated further as Radi was assassinated in theYugoslav ParliamentNational Assemblyin 1928, leading to thedictatorshipof KingAlexander I of YugoslaviaAlexanderin January 1929.cite journalRadovi Zavoda za povijesne znanosti HAZU u Zadru[[Croatian Academy of Sciences and Arts]]1330-0474http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show203–21851November 2009Zlatko BegonjaIvan Pernar o hrvatsko-srpskim odnosima nakon atentata u Beogradu 1928. godineCroatianIvan Pernar on Croatian-Serbian relations after 1928 Belgrade assassination17 October 2011The dictatorship formally ended in 1931 when the king imposed a more unitarian constitution, and changed the name of the country to Yugoslavia.cite bookYugoslavia's ruin: the bloody lessons of nationalism, a patriot's warningCvijeto Job[[Rowman & Littlefield]]978-0-7425-1784-49200227 October 2011https://books.google.com/books?idThe HSS, now led byVladko Maek, continued to advocatefederalisationof Yugoslavia, resulting in theCvetkoviMaek Agreementof August 1939 and the autonomousBanovina of Croatia. The Yugoslav government retained control of defence, internal security, foreign affairs, trade, and transport while other matters were left to the Croatian Sabor and a crown-appointed Ban.Klemeni, agar 2004, p. 121123

File:Adolf Hitler meets Ante Paveli.1941.jpgthumbleftAdolf Hitlermeets Croat leaderAnte Paveliupon his arrival at theBerghof (residence)Berghoffor a state visit, June 1941In April 1941,Invasion of YugoslaviaYugoslavia was occupiedbyNazi GermanyGermanyandKingdom of Italy (18611946)Italy. Following the invasion the territory, parts of Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the region ofSyrmiawere incorporated into theIndependent State of Croatia(NDH), a Nazi-backedpuppet state. Parts of Dalmatia were annexed by Italy and the northern Croatian regions ofBaranya (region)BaranjaandMeimurjewere annexed by Hungary.Klemeni, agar 2004, p. 153156The NDH regime was led byAnte Paveliand ultranationalistUstae. The regime introducedAntisemitismanti-semiticlaws and conducted a campaign ofWorld War II persecution of Serbsethnic cleansing and genocide against SerbandRomani peopleRomainhabitants of the NDH, exemplified by theJasenovac concentration campJasenovacandStara Gradika concentration campStara Gradikaconcentration camps.cite journalArhivski vjesnik[[Croatian State Archives]]0570-9008November 199639Josip Kolanović157–174Holocaust in Croatia – Documentation and research perspectiveshttp://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show17 October 2011

It is estimated that out of 39,000Jewsin the country only 9,000 survived; the rest were either killed or deported to Germany, both by the local authorities and the German Army itself.cite book[[Richard S. Levy]]Antisemitism: a historical encyclopedia of prejudice and persecution978-1-85109-439-4149–150[[ABC-CLIO]]2005https://books.google.com/books?id17 October 2011Croatian and Serbian sources disagree on the exact figures.cite bookhttps://books.google.com/books?id[[Bogoljub Kočović]]Sahrana jednog mita: žrtve Drugog svetskog rata u JugoslavijiSerbianBurial of a Myth: World War II Victims in YugoslaviaOtkrovenje2005978-86-83353-39-218 October 2011Furthermore, a significant number of Serbs were killed by the Ustae on the territory of the NDH during the war. According to Midlarsky, number of Serbs killed by the regime was at least half a million,#MidlarskyMidlarsky (2005), p. 131; quote: "Memories of the mass murder of at least 500,000 Serbs by the fascist Croatian state in alliance with Nazi Germany during World War II were rekindled by Tuman's behavior."but the figure is contradicted by bothBogoljub KooviandVladimir erjavi. Koovi estimated total number of Serbs killed throughout Yugoslav territory in various circumstances at 487,000, while erjavi put the figure at 530,000. Furthermore, erjavi indicated that 320,000 Serbs were killed in the NDH, including 82,000 killed among the Yugoslav Partisans, 23,000 killed as Axis collaborators, 25,000 victims of typhoid epidemic, 45,000 killed by Germans and 15,000 by Italians. Koovi's and erjavi's total Yugoslav losses are in agreement with estimates made by Mayers and Campbell of theUnited States Census Bureau.cite bookPhilip J. CohenDavid RiesmanSerbia's Secret War: Propaganda and the Deceit of History978-0-89096-760-7109–110[[Texas A&M University Press]]1996https://books.google.com/books?id17 October 2011The number of Croats killed in the NDH is estimated to be approximately 200,000, either by the Croatian fascist regime, as members of the armed resistance, or asAxis powersAxis collaborators.cite bookPhilip J. CohenDavid RiesmanSerbia's Secret War: Propaganda and the Deceit of History978-0-89096-760-7106–111[[Texas A&M University Press]]1996https://books.google.com/books?id17 October 2011Several thousand of these were killed by the Chetniks; most Croatian historians place the number of Croats killed by the Chetniks on the territory of modern-day Croatia at between 3,000 and 3,500. Croatian estimates for the number of Croats killed by Chetniks in the whole of Yugoslavia range from 18,000 to 32,000 (both combatants and civilians).cite journalVladimir GeigerCroatian Institute of HistoryHuman Losses of the Croats in World War II and the Immediate Post-War Period Caused by the Chetniks (Yugoslav Army in the Fatherand) and the Partisans (People's Liberation Army and the Partisan Detachments of Yugoslavia/Yugoslav Army) and the Communist Authorities: Numerical Indicatorshttp://hrcak.srce.hr/103223?lang85–87

File:Josip Broz Tito uniform portrait.jpgthumbuprightThe CroatJosip Broz Titowas the leader of Yugoslavia from 1944 to 1980.A resistance movement soon emerged. On 22 June 1941,Dragutin Pavlievi, Povijest Hrvatske, Naklada Pavii, Zagreb, 2007., ISBN 978-953-6308-71-2, str. 441. 442.theSisak People's Liberation Partisan Detachment1st Sisak Partisan Detachmentwas formed nearSisak, as the first military unit formed by a resistance movement inGerman-occupied Europeoccupied Europe.cite bookDragutin PavličevićPovijest Hrvatske2007Naklada Pavičić978-953-6308-71-2441–442This sparked the beginning of theYugoslav Partisanmovement, a communist multi-ethnic anti-fascist resistance group led byJosip Broz Tito.cite news[[Večernji list]]Croatianhttp://www.vecernji.hr/vijesti/josipovic-antifasizam-je-duhovni-otac-domovinskog-rata-clanak-303250Josipović: Antifašizam je duhovni otac Domovinskog rataJosipović: Anti-Fascism is a Spiritual Forerunner of the Croatian War of Independence22 June 2011Matea Vipotnik14 October 201126 July 2012nohttp://www.webcitation.org/69QlU80FoThe movement grew rapidly and at theTehran Conferencein December 1943 the Partisans gained recognition from theAllies of World War IIAllies.cite journalHistorijski zbornik0351-2193Društvo za hrvatsku povjesnicuDecember 2008612Karakaš Obradov MaricaSaveznički zračni napadi na Split i okolicu i djelovanje Narodne zaštite u Splitu tijekom Drugog svjetskog rataAllied aerial attacks on Split and its surrounding and Civil Guard activity in Split during the World War IICroatianhttp://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show323–34917 October 2011

With Allied support in logistics, equipment, training and air power, and with the assistance ofRed ArmySoviet troopstaking part in the 1944Belgrade Offensive, the Partisans gained control of Yugoslavia and the border regions ofTrieste#World War II and its aftermathItalyandCarinthia (state)#From 1920 to the PresentAustriaby May 1945, during which time thousands of members of the Ustae, as well as Croat refugees, wereBleiburg repatriationskilledby the Yugoslav Partisans.cite encyclopediahttp://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/143561/Croatia/223956/World-War-IIHistory of Croatia, World War IIC.W. Bracewell, John R. LampeEncyclopædia Britannica OnlineEncyclopædia Britannica Inc.201225 March 2013The political aspirations of the Partisan movement were reflected in theState Anti-fascist Council for the National Liberation of Croatia, which developed in 1943 as the bearer of Croatian statehood and later transformed into the Parliament of Croatia in 1945, andAVNOJits counterpart at the Yugoslav level.cite journalPro tempore – časopis studenata povijestiKlub studenata povijesti ISHA1334-8302Marko MaurovićJosip protiv JosifaJosip vs. IosifCroatian73–831May 2004http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show17 October 2011cite webSaborhttp://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?artCroatianPredsjednik Sabora Luka Bebić na obilježavanju 64. obljetnice pobjede nad fašizmom i 65. obljetnice trećeg zasjedanja ZAVNOH-a u TopuskomSpeaker of the Parliament, Luka Bebić, at celebration of the 64th anniversary of the victory over fascism and the 65th anniversary of the 3rd session of the ZAVNOH session in Topusko9 May 200917 October 201126 July 2012nohttp://www.webcitation.org/69QllTBy8

AfterWorld War II, Croatia became asingle-partysocialistSocialist Republic of Croatiafederal unitof theSocialist Federal Republic of YugoslaviaSFR Yugoslavia, ruled by theLeague of Communists of CroatiaCommunists, but enjoying a degree of autonomy within the federation. In 1967, Croatian authors and linguists published aDeclaration on the Status and Name of the Croatian Standard Languagedemanding greater autonomy forCroatian language.cite journalRadovi Zavoda za hrvatsku povijest3110353-295X317–318Deklaracija o nazivu i položaju hrvatskog književnog jezika – Građa za povijest DeklaracijeDeclaration on the Status and Name of the Croatian Standard Language – Declaration History ArticlesIvica ŠuteApril 1999Croatianhttp://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?showThe declaration contributed to a national movement seeking greater civil rights and decentralisation of the Yugoslav economy, culminating in theCroatian Springof 1971, suppressed by Yugoslav leadership.cite news[[Jutarnji list]]Croatianhttp://www.jutarnji.hr/heroina-hrvatskog-proljeca/305499/Heroina Hrvatskog proljećaHeroine of the Croatian Spring6 August 2009Vlado Vurušić14 October 201126 July 2012nohttp://www.webcitation.org/69QmExEdPStill, the1974 Yugoslav Constitutiongave increased autonomy to federal units, basically fulfilling a goal of the Croatian Spring, and providing a legal basis for independence of the federative constituents.cite journalRoland RichRecognition of States: The Collapse of Yugoslavia and the Soviet UnionEuropean Journal of International Law19931436–65http://www.ejil.org/article.php?article18 October 2011

Following the death of Yugoslav rulerJosip Broz TitoTitoin 1980, the 1980s the political situation in Yugoslavia deteriorated with national tension fanned by the 1986 SerbianMemorandum of the Serbian Academy of Sciences and ArtsSANU Memorandumand the1989 coups in Vojvodina, Kosovo and Montenegro.Frucht 2005, p. 433cite news[[Reuters]]http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?resLeaders of a with the CroatianPolitical factionfactiondemanding a looser federation.cite journalDavor PaukovićCentar za politološka istraživanjahttp://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?showCroatianPosljednji kongres Saveza povijest1121–33PDF1847-239711 December 2010In the same year, theCroatian parliamentary election, 1990first multi-party electionswere held in Croatia, withFranjo Tuman's win raising nationalist tensions further.cite news[[The Independent]]http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/obituary-franjo-tudjman-1132142.htmlObituary: Franjo TudjmanBranka Magas13 December 199917 October 201126 July 2012nohttp://www.webcitation.org/69Qmjvz7eSerbs of CroatiaSerbs in Croatialeft Sabor and declared the autonomy of areas that would soon become the unrecognisedRepublic of Serbian Krajina, intent on achieving independence from Croatia.cite newsThe New York Timeshttp://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/02/world/croatia-s-serbs-declare-their-autonomy.html[[Chuck Sudetic]]Croatia's Serbs Declare Their article.heading: Independence (1991)
article.paragraph: File:Croatian War 1991 Vukovar destroyed tank.jpgthumbA Yugoslav tank destroyed during the 1991Battle of VukovarAs tensions rose, CroatiaIndependence of Croatiadeclared independencein June 1991, however the declaration came into effect on 8 October 1991.cite newsThe New York Timeshttp://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/26/world/2-yugoslav-states-vote-independence-to-press-demands.html2 Yugoslav States Vote Independence To Press DemandsChuck Sudetic26 June 199112 December 2010http://www.webcitation.org/69Wj75HVR29 July 2012nocite webOfficial web site of the Croatian ParliamentSaborhttp://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?artCeremonial session of the Croatian Parliament on the occasion of the Day of Independence of the Republic of Croatia7 October 200429 July 201229 July 2012nohttp://www.webcitation.org/69Wk9bFY8In the meantime, tensions escalated into theCroatian War of Independencewhen theYugoslav National Armyand various SerbParamilitaryparamilitariesattacked Croatia.cite newsThe New York Timeshttp://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/04/world/army-rushes-to-take-a-croatian-town.html?refArmy Rushes to Take a Croatian Town[[Chuck Sudetic]]4 November 199129 July 201229 July 2012nohttp://www.webcitation.org/69WkpvqwnBy the end of 1991, a high intensity war fought along a wide front reduced Croatia to control of about two-thirds of its territory.cite newsThe New York Timeshttp://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/20/world/croatia-clashes-rise-mediators-pessimistic.htmlCroatia Clashes Rise; Mediators Pessimistic19 December 199129 July 201229 July 2012nohttp://www.webcitation.org/69WlHzDK7cite news[[Los Angeles Times]]http://articles.latimes.com/1991-08-01/news/mn-177_1_defense-forceSerbian Forces Press Fight for Major Chunk of Croatia[[Charles T. Powers]]1 August 199129 July 201229 July 2012nohttp://www.webcitation.org/69WlatGyyOn 15 January 1992, Croatia gaineddiplomatic recognitionby theEuropean Economic Communitymembers, and subsequently theUnited Nations.cite newsThe New York Timeshttp://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/24/world/slovenia-and-croatia-get-bonn-s-nod.htmlSlovenia and Croatia Get Bonn's Nod[[Stephen Kinzer]]24 December 199129 July 201229 July 2012nohttp://www.webcitation.org/69WmZTuSScite newshttp://www.nytimes.com/1992/05/23/world/3-ex-yugoslav-republics-are-accepted-into-un.html3 Ex-Yugoslav Republics Are Accepted Into U.N.[[The New York Times]][[Paul L. Montgomery]]23 May 199229 July 201229 July 2012nohttp://www.webcitation.org/69WnEWOSKThe war effectively ended in 1995 with aOperation Stormdecisive victoryby Croatia in August 1995.cite newsLos Angeles Timeshttp://articles.latimes.com/1995-08-08/news/mn-32662_1_serb-refugeesCroats Declare Victory, End BlitzDean E. Murphy8 August 199518 December 20104 August 2012nohttp://www.webcitation.org/69fL2KrVNThe remaining occupied areas were restored to Croatia pursuant to theErdut Agreementof November 1995, with the process concluded in January 1998.cite news[[The New York Times]]http://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/16/world/an-ethnic-morass-is-returned-to-croatia.htmlAn Ethnic Morass Is Returned to Croatia[[Chris Hedges]]16 January 199818 December 20104 August 2012nohttp://www.webcitation.org/69fNS26LXCroatia became aWorld Trade Organization(WTO) member on 30 November 2000. The country signed aStabilization and Association Agreement(SAA) with the European Union in October 2001. Croatia became member of NATO on 1 April 2009, and2013 enlargement of the European Unionjoinedthe European Union on 1 July 2013.
article.heading: Geography
article.paragraph: Croatia is located inCentral EuropeCentralandSoutheast Europe, borderingHungaryto the northeast,Serbiato the east,Bosnia and Herzegovinato the southeast,Montenegroto the southeast, theAdriatic Seato the southwest andSloveniato the northwest. It lies mostly between latitudes42nd parallel north42and47th parallel north47 Nand longitudes13th meridian east13and20th meridian east20 E. Part of the territory in the extreme south surroundingDubrovnikis apractical exclaveconnected to the rest of the mainland byterritorial waters, but separated on land by a short coastline strip belonging to Bosnia and Herzegovina aroundNeum.The territory coversconvert56594km2sqmi0off, consisting ofconvert56414km2sqmi0offof land andconvert128km2sqmi0offof water. It is the 127th largest country in the world.Elevation ranges from the mountains of theDinaric Alpswith the highest point of theDinarapeak atconvert1831mftoffnear the border with Bosnia and Herzegovina in the southto the shore of the Adriatic Sea which makes up its entire southwest border. Insular Croatia consists of overList of islands of Croatiaa thousand islands and isletsvarying in size, 48 of which areList of inhabited islands of Croatiapermanently inhabited. The largest islands areCresandKrk,each of them having an area of aroundconvert405km2off.The hilly northern parts ofHrvatsko Zagorjeand the flat plains ofSlavoniain the east (which is part of thePannonian Basin) are traversed by major rivers such asSava,Drava,KupaandDanube. The Danube, Europe's second longest river, runs through the city ofVukovarin the extreme east and forms part of the border with Serbia. The central and southern regions near the Adriatic coastline and islands consist of low mountains and forested highlands. Natural resources found in the country in quantities significant enough for production include oil, coal, bauxite, low-grade iron ore, calcium, gypsum, natural asphalt, silica, mica, clays, salt and hydropower.Karst topographymakes up about half of Croatia and is especially prominent in the Dinaric Alps.cite webhttp://www.geografija.hr/clanci/1011/rasirenost-krsa-u-hrvatskojRaširenost krša u HrvatskojPresence of Karst in CroatiaCroatianCroatian Geographic Society18 December 2006Mate Matas18 October 2011geografija.hr8 August 2012nohttp://www.webcitation.org/69lbXToZSThere areList of caves in Croatiaa number of deep caves in Croatia, 49 of which are deeper thanconvert250m2on, 14 of them deeper thanconvert500m2onand three deeper thanconvert1000m2on. Croatia's most famous lakes are thePlitvice Lakes National ParkPlitvice lakes, a system of 16 lakes with waterfalls connecting them overdolomiteandlimestonecascades. The lakes are renowned for their distinctive colours, ranging from turquoise to mint green, grey or blue.cite webBBChttp://www.bbc.com/travel/feature/20110617-the-best-national-parks-of-europeThe best national parks of Europe28 June 201111 October 20114 August 2012nohttp://www.webcitation.org/69fOQEt30
article.heading: Climate
article.paragraph: File:Plitvice Lakes National Park (2).jpgthumbPlitvice Lakes National Park, a UNESCOWorld Heritage Site.File:Ravni kotari.JPGthumbRavni Kotari, a geographical region inDalmatia.Most of Croatia has a moderately warm and rainycontinental climateas defined by theKppen climate classification. Mean monthly temperature ranges betweenconvert-3°C°Fon(in January) andconvert18°C°Foff(in July). The coldest parts of the country areLikaandGorski Kotarwhere snowy forested climate is found at elevations aboveconvert1200mftoff. The warmest areas of Croatia are at the Adriatic coast and especially in its immediate hinterland characterised by theMediterranean climate, as the temperature highs are moderated by the sea. Consequently, temperature peaks are more pronounced in the continental areasthe lowest temperature ofconvert-35.5°C°Foffwas recorded on 3 February 1919 inakovec, and the highest temperature ofconvert42.4°C°Foffwas recorded on 5 July 1950 inKarlovac.harvnb2013 Statistical Yearbook of the Republic of Croatia36Mean annual precipitation ranges betweenconvert600mminoffandconvert3500mminoffdepending on geographic region and prevailing climate type. The least precipitation is recorded in the outer islands (Vis,Lastovo,Bievo,Svetac) and in the eastern parts of Slavonia, however in the latter case, it is mostly occurring during thegrowing season. The maximum precipitation levels are observed on the Dinara mountain range and in Gorski kotar.cite web[[Croatian Bureau of Statistics]]http://www.dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/ljetopis/2010/SLJH2010.pdfPDF2010 – Statistical Yearbook of the Republic of CroatiaDecember 20107 October 2011Prevailing winds in the interior are light to moderate northeast or southwest, and in the coastal area prevailing winds are determined by local area features. Higher wind velocities are more often recorded in cooler months along the coast, generally asBora (wind)buraor less frequently assirocco. The sunniest parts of the country are the outer islands, Hvar andKorula, where more than 2700 hours of sunshine are recorded per year, followed by the southern Adriatic Sea area in general, northern Adriatic coast, and Slavonia, all with more than 2000 hours of sunshine per year.harvnb2013 Statistical Yearbook of the Republic of Croatia37
article.heading: Biodiversity
article.paragraph: MainProtected areas of CroatiaFile:6tyuk.jpgthumbrightKopaki Ritnature park, one of the largestwetlandsin EuropeCroatia can be subdivided between a number ofecoregionsbecause of its climate and geomorphology, and the country is consequently one of the richest in Europe in terms of biodiversity. There are four types of biogeographical regions in CroatiaMediterranean along the coast and in its immediate hinterland, Alpine in most of Lika and Gorski Kotar, Pannonian along Drava and Danube, and continental in the remaining areas. One of the most significant arekarsthabitats which include submerged karst, such asZrmanjaandKrka (Croatia)Krkacanyons and tufa barriers, as well as underground habitats. The karst geology harbours approximatelyList of caves in Croatia7,000 caves and pits, some of which are habitat of the only known aquatic cavevertebratetheolm. Forests are also significantly present in the country, as they coverconvert2490000haoffrepresenting 44% of Croatian land surface. The other habitat types include wetlands, grasslands, bogs, fens, scrub habitats, coastal and marine habitats.cite bookState Institute for Nature Protection, [[Ministry of Culture (Croatia)]]PDFhttp://www.dzzp.hr/dokumenti_upload/20120515/dzzp201205151608230.pdfBiodiversity of Croatia2006Jasminka RadovićKristijan ČivićRamona Topić953-7169-20-013 October 2011In terms ofphytogeography, Croatia is a part of theBoreal Kingdomand is a part of Illyrian and Central European provinces of theCircumboreal Regionand the Adriatic province of theMediterranean Region. TheWorld Wide Fund for Naturedivides Croatia between three ecoregionsPannonian mixed forests,Dinaric Mountains mixed forestsandIllyrian deciduous forests.cite web6th Dubrovnik Conference on Sustainable Development of Energy, Water and Environment Systemshttp://www.dubrovnik2011.sdewes.org/venue.phpVenue13 October 2011File:Karstformationen Nationalpark-Nord-Velebit.JPGthumbKarstinNational Park Sjeverni Velebit.There are 37,000 known species in Croatia, but their actual number is estimated to be between 50,000 and 100,000.The claim is supported by nearly 400 new taxa ofinvertebratesdiscovered in Croatia in the first half of the 2000s (decade) alone.There are more than a thousand endemic species, especially in Velebit and Biokovo mountains, Adriatic islands and karst rivers. Legislation protects 1,131 species.The most serious threat to species is loss and degradation of habitats. A further problem is presented by appearance of invasive alien species, especiallyCaulerpa taxifoliaalgae. The invasive algae are regularly monitored and removed to protect theBenthic zonebenthic habitat. Indigenous sorts of cultivated plants and breeds of domesticated animals are also numerous. Those include five breeds of horses, five breeds of cattle, eight breeds of sheep, two breeds of pigs and a poultry breed. Even the indigenous breeds include nine endangered or critically endangered ones.There are 444protected areas of Croatia, encompassing 9% of the country. Those include eightList of national parks of Croatianational parks, two strict reserves, and tennature parks. The most famous protected area and the oldestnational parkin Croatia is the Plitvice Lakes National Park, aWorld Heritage Sites in CroatiaUNESCO World Heritage Site. Velebit Nature Park is a part of the UNESCOMan and the Biosphere Programme. The strict and special reserves, as well as the national and nature parks, are managed and protected by the central government, while other protected areas are managed by counties. In 2005, the National Ecological Network was set up, as the first step in preparation of the EU accession and joining of theNatura 2000network.
article.heading: Politics

template.arg: List of political parties in Croatia

link.part: Banski dvori, former seat of Croatianban (title)bansand current seat of theCroatian Government
Seat of theConstitutional Court of Croatia

article.paragraph: The Republic of Croatia is aunitary stateusing aparliamentary systemof governance. With the collapse of the ruling communist party in SFR Yugoslavia, Croatia organized its firstMulti-party systemmulti-party electionsand adopted itsConstitution of Croatiapresent constitutionin 1990.cite newsThe New York Timeshttp://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/09/world/evolution-in-europe-conservatives-win-in-croatia.html?refEVOLUTION IN EUROPE; Conservatives Win in Croatia9 May 199014 October 2011ItDeclaration of independencedeclared independenceon 8 October 1991 leading to theBreakup of Yugoslaviabreak-up of Yugoslaviaand the country was internationally recognised by the United Nations in 1992.Under its 1990 constitution, Croatia operated asemi-presidential systemuntil 2000 when it switched to a parliamentary system.cite newsBBC Newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1097128.stmCroatia country profile20 July 201114 October 2011Government powers in Croatia are divided into legislative, executive and judiciary powers.cite web[[Government of Croatia]]http://www.vlada.hr/en/about_croatia/information/political_structurePolitical Structure6 May 200714 October 2011Thelegal systemof Croatia iscivil law (legal system)civil law, strongly influenced, as is the institutional framework, by the legal heritage of Austria-Hungary.cite bookTomasz GiaroModernisierung durch Transfer im 19. und frühen 20. Jahrhundert Von Tomasz Giarohttps://books.google.com/?id2006Vittorio Klostermann978-3-465-03489-6German15 October 2011By the timeAccession of Croatia to the European UnionEU accession negotiationswere completed on 30 June 2010, Croatian legislation was fully harmonised with theCommunity acquis.cite webDelegation of the European Union to the Republic of Croatiahttp://www.delhrv.ec.europa.eu/?langOverview of EU – Croatia relations14 October 2011

ThePresident of CroatiaPresident of the Republic(lang-hrPredsjednik Republike) is thehead of state, directly elected to a five-year term and is limited by the Constitution to a maximum of two terms. In addition to being thecommander in chiefof the armed forces, the president has the procedural duty of appointing the prime minister with the consent of the parliament, and has some influence on foreign policy.The most recent presidential elections were held on 11 January 2015, whenKolinda Grabar-Kitaroviwon. She took theoath of officeon 15 February 2015.cite webOffice of the President of the Republic of Croatiahttp://www.predsjednik.hr/PRESIDENTIvo Josipović – biography14 October 2011

TheCroatian Governmentgovernmentis headed by thePrime Minister of Croatiaprime minister, who has four deputy prime ministers and 17 ministers in charge of particular sectors of activity.cite webGovernment of Croatiahttp://www.vlada.hr/en/naslovnica/o_vladi_rh/clanovi_vladeMembers of the Government14 October 2011As theExecutive (government)executive branch, it is responsible for proposing legislation and a budget, executing the laws, and guiding the foreign and internal policies of the republic. The government is seated atBanski dvoriin Zagreb.Since 23 December 2011, the prime minister of the government has beenZoran Milanovi.cite news[[Večernji list]]http://www.vecernji.hr/vijesti/premijer-zoran-milanovic-ministri-polozili-prisegu-kao-clanovi-vlade-clanak-359347Premijer Zoran Milanović i ministri položili prisegu kao članovi VladePrime minister Zoran Milanović and ministers sworn in as members of the governmentCroatian23 December 2011Marinela Vidić-Ivoš23 December 2011

TheCroatian Parliamentparliament(langhrSabor) is aunicamerallegislative body. A secondchambers of parliamentchamber, theHouse of Counties, set up in 1993 pursuant to the 1990 Constitution, was abolished in 2001. The number of Sabor members can vary from 100 to 160; they are all elected by popular vote to serve four-year terms. The sessions of the Sabor take place from 15 January to 15 July, and from 15 September to 15 December.cite webSaborhttp://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?secAbout the Parliament14 October 2011The two largest political parties in Croatia are theCroatian Democratic Unionand theSocial Democratic Party of Croatia.cite webSaborMembers of the 6th Parliamenthttp://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?sec14 October 2011

Croatia has a three-tiered judicial system, made up of theCroatian Supreme CourtSupreme Court,County CourtCounty courts, and Municipal courts. TheCroatian Constitutional CourtConstitutional Courtrules on matters regarding the Constitution. In addition there are misdemeanour courts, commercial courts and administrative courts.cite web[[Croatian Supreme Court]]http://www.vsrh.hr/EasyWeb.asp?pcpidCroatianUstavne odredbeProvisions of the Constitution21 May 201014 October 2011Law enforcement in Croatia is the responsibility of the Croatian police force, which is under the control of theMinistry of the Interior (Croatia)Ministry of the Interior. In recent years, the force has been undergoing a reform with assistance from international agencies, including theOrganization for Security and Co-operation in Europe(OSCE) since its mission to Croatia began on 18 April 1996.cite web[[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe]]PDFSTATUS REPORT No.16 ON CROATIA'S PROGRESS IN MEETING INTERNATIONAL COMMITMENTS SINCE NOVEMBER 20047 July 2005http://www.osce.org/zagreb/1598513 October 2011
article.heading: Administrative divisions
article.paragraph: FurtherCounties of CroatiaNUTS of CroatiaFile:Split iz zraka.jpgthumbrightThe center of the city ofSplit, CroatiaSplit, built in and around theDiocletian's PalacePalace of the Emperor Diocletian.Croatia was first subdivided into counties in theMiddle Ages.cite journal[[Školska knjiga]]Historijski zbornik51–21952PDFhttp://www.historiografija.hr/hz/1952/HZ_5_11_MANDIC.pdfOleg MandićCroatianO nekim pitanjima društvenog uređenja Hrvatske u srednjem vijekuOn some issues of social system of Croatia in the Middle Ages131–1389 September 2011The divisions changed over time to reflect losses of territory to Ottoman conquest and subsequent liberation of the same territory, changes of political status ofDalmatia, Dubrovnik andIstria. Traditional division of the country into counties was abolished in the 1920s, when the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes and subsequent Kingdom of Yugoslavia introducedoblastsandSubdivisions of the Kingdom of Yugoslaviabanovinasrespectively.Frucht 2005, pp. 429429

Communist ruled Croatia, as a constituent part of post-WWII Yugoslavia, abolished earlier divisions and introduced municipalities, subdividing Croatia into approximately one hundred municipalities. Counties were reintroduced in 1992 legislation, significantly altered in terms of territory relative to the pre-1920s subdivisions: In 1918, theTransleithanianpart of Croatia was divided into eight counties with their seats inBjelovar,Gospi,Ogulin,Poega, CroatiaPoega,Vukovar,Varadin,Osijekand Zagreb, and the 1992 legislation established 14 counties in the same territory.Biondich 2000, p. 11cite news[[Narodne novine]]30 December 19929 September 2011CroatianZakon o područjima županija, gradova i općina u Republici HrvatskojTerritories of Counties, Cities and Municipalities of the Republic of Croatia Acthttp://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/1992_12_90_2333.html

Since the counties were re-established in 1992, Croatia is divided into 20 counties and the capital city of Zagreb, the latter having the authority and legal status of a county and a city at the same time. Borders of the counties changed in some instances since, with the latest revision taking place in 2006. The counties subdivide into 127List of cities in Croatiacitiesand 429Municipalities of Croatiamunicipalities.cite newsNarodne novine28 July 20069 September 2011CroatianZakon o područjima županija, gradova i općina u Republici HrvatskojTerritories of Counties, Cities and Municipalities of the Republic of Croatia Acthttp://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/2006_07_86_2045.htmlNomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics(NUTS)NUTS of Croatiadivision of Croatiais performed in several tiers. NUTS 1 level places the entire country in a single unit, while there are three NUTS 2 regions. Those are Northwest Croatia, Central and Eastern (Pannonian) Croatia and Adriatic Croatia. The latter encompasses all the counties along the Adriatic coast. The Northwest Croatia includes the city of Zagreb, Zagreb, Krapina-Zagorje, Varadin, Koprivnica-Krievci and Meimurje counties, and the Central and Eastern (Pannonian) Croatia includes the remaining areasBjelovar-Bilogora, Virovitica-Podravina, Poega-Slavonia, Brod-Posavina, Osijek-Baranja, Vukovar-Syrmia, Karlovac and Sisak-Moslavina counties. Individual counties and the city of Zagreb also represent NUTS 3 level subdivision units in Croatia. The NUTSLocal administrative unitdivisions are two-tiered. LAU 1 divisions match the counties and the city of Zagreb in effect making those the same as NUTS 3 units, while LAU 2 subdivisions correspond to the cities and municipalities of Croatia.cite web[[Council of Europe]]PDFCroatianhttp://www.coe.int/t/dg4/cultureheritage/heritage/cemat/confminist1-15/15eCEMAT_National_Report_Croatia_2010_HR.pdfNacionalno izviješće HrvatskaCroatia National ReportJanuary 201025 February 2012
article.heading: Foreign relations
article.paragraph: Croatia has established diplomatic relations with 174 countries.cite webt-portalhttp://www.tportal.hr/vijesti/svijet/126015/Vatikan-nije-medu-prvima-priznao-Hrvatsku.htmlCroatianS kojim državama nemamo diplomatske odnose?Which countries do we have no diplomatic relations with?Drago Pilsel5 May 201124 September 2011As of 2009, Croatia maintains a network of 51 embassies, 24 consulates and eight permanent diplomatic missions abroad. Furthermore, there are 52 foreign embassies and 69Consul (representative)consulatesin the Republic of Croatia in addition to offices of international organisations such as theEuropean Bank for Reconstruction and Development,International Organization for Migration, OSCE,World Bank,World Health Organization(WHO),International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia(ICTY),United Nations Development Programme,United Nations High Commissioner for RefugeesandUNICEF.cite web[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and European Integration (Croatia)]]http://www.mfa.hr/MVP.asp?pcpidDiplomatic Missions and Consular Offices to Croatia24 September 2011In 2009, the CroatianMinistry of Foreign Affairs and European Integration (Croatia)Ministry of Foreign Affairs and European Integrationemployed 1,381 personnel and expended 648.2 million kuna (86.4 million).cite webState Audit Office (Croatia)CroatianPDFhttp://www.revizija.hr/izvjesca/2011-rr-2009-poseban-dio/03_ministarstvo_vanjskih_poslova_i_europskih_integracija.pdfIzviješće o obavljenoj reviziji – Ministarstvo vanjskih poslova i europskih integracijaAudit Report – Ministry of Foreign Affairs and European IntegrationAugust 201024 September 2010Stated aims of Croatian foreign policy include enhancing relations with neighbouring countries, developing international co-operation and promotion of the Croatian economy and Croatia itself.cite webMinistry of Foreign Affairs and European Integration (Croatia)http://un.mfa.hr/?mhForeign Policy Aims24 September 2011File:Svecanost podizanja NATOve zastave Zagreb 77.jpgthumbFlag hoisting ceremony atMinistry of Defence (Croatia)Ministry of Defencein Zagreb, marking joining of theNATOin 2009Since 2003, Croatian foreign policy has focused on achieving the strategic goal of becoming amember state of the European Union(EU).cite web[[Nacional (weekly)]]http://www.nacional.hr/clanak/21036/mesiceva-podrska-un-u-blokira-ulazak-hrvatske-u-natoCroatiaMesićeva podrška UN-u blokira ulazak Hrvatske u NATOMesić's support to the UN blocks Croatian NATO accession17 October 2005Eduard Šoštarić24 September 201130 June 2012nohttp://www.webcitation.org/68ocR483Hcite webSaborhttp://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?artIzvješća o aktivnostima saborskih dužnosnika – rujan 2005: Odbor za parlamentarnu suradnju i odnose s javnošću Skupštine Zapadnoeuropske unije posjetio Hrvatski saborReport on activities of Parliament officials – September 2005: Western European Union parliamentary cooperation and public relations committee visits Croatian ParliamentCroatian26 September 200524 September 2011In December 2011, Croatia completed the EU accession negotiations and signedTreaty of Accession 2011an EU accession treatyon 9 December 2011.cite webhttp://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?referenceEU closes accession negotiations with Croatia30 June 2011[[European Commission]]24 September 2011cite web[[European Union]]http://europa.eu/news/external-relations/2011/03/20110302_en.htmCroatia signs EU accession treaty9 December 201112 December 2011Croatia joined theEuropean Unionon 1 July 2013 marking the end of a process started in 2001 by signing of theStabilisation and Association ProcessStabilisation and Association Agreementand Croatian application for the EU membership in 2003.cite newsThe New York Timeshttp://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/11/world/europe/11iht-croatia11.htmlCroatia Given Conditional Approval to Join E.U. in 201310 June 2011Stephen Castle24 September 2011A recurring obstacle to the negotiations was Croatia's ICTY co-operation record and Slovenian blocking of the negotiations because ofCroatiaSlovenia border disputes.cite newsBBC Newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4337777.stmEU stalls over talks with Croatia10 March 200522 December 2011cite newsBBC NewsSlovenia unblocks Croatian EU bidhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8250441.stm11 September 200922 December 2011The latter was resolved through an Arbitration Agreement of 4 November 2009, approved by national parliaments and a referendum in Slovenia.cite newsThe New York Timeshttp://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/07/world/europe/07iht-slovenia.htmlSlovenians Seem to Favor Arbitration in Border Dispute With Croatia6 June 2010[[Reuters]]24 September 2011

Another strategic Croatian foreign policy goal for the 2000s wasCroatiaNATO relationsNATO membership.Croatia was included in thePartnership for Peacein 2000, invited toNATOmembership in 2008 and formally joined the alliance on 1 April 2009.cite newsThe New York Timeshttp://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/05/world/europe/05cnd-prexy.htmlBush Champions Expansive Mission for NATO5 April 2008Steven Lee Myers24 September 2011cite newsBBC Newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7977332.stmNato welcomes Albania and Croatia1 April 200924 September 2011Croatia became a member of theUnited Nations Security Councilfor the 20082009 term, assuming presidency in December 2008.cite webMinistry of Foreign Affairs and European Integration (Croatia)http://www.mvpei.hr/mvp.asp?pcpidMembership of the Republic of Croatia in the UN Security Council 2008–200924 September 2011The country is preparing to join theSchengen Areaby 2015.cite newshttp://www.vecernji.hr/vijesti/karamarko-granicni-nadzor-prema-eu-ukidamo-2015-clanak-248519Karamarko: Granični nadzor prema EU ukidamo 2015.Karamarko: Border control towards the EU shall be abolished in 2015CroatianStojan de Prato4 February 2011Večernji list2 July 2011
article.heading: Military
article.paragraph: Croatian Armed Forces (CAF) consist of theCroatian ArmyArmy,Croatian NavyNavyandCroatian Air Force and Air DefenceAir Forcebranches in addition to the Education and Training Command and Support Command. The CAF is headed by theGeneral Staff of the Armed Forces of the Republic of CroatiaGeneral Staff, which reports to theMinistry of Defence (Croatia)Defence Minister, who in turn reports to the President of Croatia. According to the constitution, the President iscommander-in-chiefof the armed forces and in case of immediate threat during wartime he issues orders directly to the General Staff.cite webhttp://www.osrh.hr/prikaz_en.asp?idiChain of Command in the CAFCroatian Ministry of Defence2 July 2012File:US Navy 021029-N-1955P-020 Navy aircraft participate in Joint Wings 2002.jpgthumbleftCroatian Air ForceandUS Navyaircraft participate in multinational training.

Following the 199195 war defence spending and CAF size have been in constant decline. As of 2005 military spending was an estimated 2.39% of the country'sGDP, which placed Croatia 64th in a ranking of all countries.cite webhttps://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/hr.htmlWorld Factbook9 September 2011[[Central Intelligence Agency]]Since 2005 the budget was kept below 2% of GDP, down from the record high of 11.1% in 1994.cite webhttp://milexdata.sipri.org/SIPRI Military Expenditure Database[[Stockholm International Peace Research Institute]]9 September 2011Traditionally relying on a large number of conscripts, CAF also went through a period of reforms focused on downsizing, restructuring andprofessionalisationin the years prior toAccession of Croatia to NATOCroatia's accession to NATOin April 2009. According to a presidential decree issued in 2006 the CAF is set to employ 18,100 active duty military personnel, 3,000 civilians and 2,000 voluntary conscripts between the ages of 18 and 30 in peacetime.

Compulsory conscription was abolished in January 2008.Until 2008 military service was compulsory for men at age 18 and conscripts served six-month tours of duty, reduced in 2001 from the earlier scheme of nine-month conscription tours. Conscientious objectors could instead opt for an eight-month civilian service.cite newshttp://www.monitor.hr/clanci/vojni-rok-u-hrvatskoj-kraci-nego-drugdje-u-europi-i-nato-u/11191/Vojni rok u Hrvatskoj kraći, nego drugdje u Europi i NATO-uMilan Jelovac23 January 2001VjesnikCroatian9 September 2011

As of20114the Croatian military had 120 members stationed in foreign countries as part of United Nations-led international peacekeeping forces, including 95 serving as part of theUnited Nations Disengagement Observer Force ZoneUNDOFin theGolan Heights.cite webhttp://www.morh.hr/hr/smos-broj-pripadnika-osrh-u-mirovnim-misijama-un-a.htmlBroj pripadnika OSRH u mirovnim misijama UN-a16 April 2011Croatian Ministry of DefenceCroatian9 September 2011As of 2011 an additional 350 troops serve as part of the NATO-ledInternational Security Assistance ForceISAFforce in Afghanistan and another 20 with theKosovo ForceKFORinKosovo.cite newshttp://www.ezadar.hr/clanak/hrvatska-salje-jos-vojnika-u-afganistanHrvatska šalje još vojnika u Afganistan8 December 2010eZadarCroatian9 September 2011cite newshttp://www.index.hr/vijesti/clanak/kosorica-u-sluzbenom-posjetu-kosovu/567980.aspxKosorica u službenom posjetu Kosovu24 August 2011[[Index.hr]]Croatian9 September 2011

Croatia also has a significantmilitary industrysector which exported around US$120 million worth of military equipment and armament in 2010.cite newshttp://www.vjesnik.hr/Article.aspx?ID14 June 2012yeshttp://www.webcitation.org/68PYXcfwAHrvatski izvoz oružja i opreme lani narastao na 650 milijuna kunaFraničevićMile6 March 2011VjesnikCroatian9 September 2011Croatian-made weapons and vehicles used by CAF include the standard sidearmHS2000manufactured byHS Produktand theM-84Dbattle tank designed by theuro akovi (factory)uro akovi factory. Uniforms and helmets worn by CAF soldiers are also locally produced and successfully marketed to other countries.
article.heading: Economy

tablerow.tablehead: The largest Croatian companies by turnover in 2010cite web[[Deloitte]]http://www.deloitte.com/view/hr_HR/hr/prijedloziiideje/deloitteovoistraivanje/5b06758a10742310VgnVCM1000001a56f00aRCRD.htmCroatian500 najvećih tvrtki Srednje Europe500 largest Central European companies9 September 20112011cite webDeloitteCroatianPDFhttp://www.deloitte.com/assets/Dcom-Croatia/Local%20Assets/Documents/2011/hr_CE%20TOP%20500_lista.pdfRang lista 500 najvećih tvrtki Srednje EuropeRanking of the 500 Largest Central European Companies11 October 2011

link.part: Croatian wineWineis produced in nearly all regions of Croatia.

article.paragraph: Croatia has aWorld Bank high-income economyhigh-incomeeconomy.cite webhttp://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/DATASTATISTICS/0,,contentMDK:20421402~pagePK:64133150~piPK:64133175~theSitePK:239419,00.html#High_incomeWorld Bank Country Classifications 2008[[World Bank]]16 May 2010International Monetary Funddata shows that Croatiannominal GDPstood at $57.371 billion, or $13,401 per capita in 2013, whilepurchasing power parityGDP was $86.570 billion, or $20,221 per capita.According toEurostatdata, Croatian PPS GDP per capita stood at 61% of the EU average in 2012.cite webhttp://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/cache/ITY_PUBLIC/2-19062013-BP/EN/2-19062013-BP-EN.PDFGDP per capita in PPS[[Eurostat]]13 December 2011

Real GDP growth in 2007 was 6.0 per cent.cite webhttp://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/portal/page?_pageidReal GDP growth rateEurostat21 May 2008//web.archive.org/web/20060822000014/http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/portal/page?_pageid22 August 2006yesThe average net salary of a Croatian worker in March 2013 was 5,516 kuna (US$988) per month.cite webhttp://www.dzs.hr/default_e.htmRepublic Of Croatia – Croatian Bureau Of StatisticsDzs.hr17 July 2012As of June 2015, registered unemployment rate in Croatia was 16.1%.cite webhttp://www.dzs.hr//Hrv/system/first_results.htmPrvi rezultatiDzs.hr6 October 2013

In 2010, economic output was dominated by theservice sectorwhich accounted for 66% of GDP, followed by theindustrial sectorwith 27.2% andagricultureaccounting for 6.8% of GDP.International Financial Statistics, IMF, May 2011According to 2004 data, 2.7% of the workforce were employed in agriculture, 32.8% by industry and 64.5% in services.cite webhttp://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2007/02/weodata/weorept.aspx?pr.xWorld Economic Outlook Database[[International Monetary Fund]]October 20079 March 2008The industrial sector is dominated by shipbuilding, food processing, pharmaceuticals, information technology, biochemical and timber industry. In 2010, Croatian exports were valued at 64.9 billion kuna (8.65 billion) with 110.3 billion kuna (14.7 billion) worth of imports. The largestinternational tradetrading partneris rest of theEuropean Union.cite webCroatian Bureau of Statisticshttp://www.dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/publication/2011/04-02-04_01_2011.htm21 October 20115 July 2011Foreign Trade in Goods of the Republic of Croatia, 2010 Final DataMore than half of Croatia's trade is with other European Union member states.cite webhttps://atlas.media.mit.edu/en/profile/country/hrv/

Privatizationand the drive toward amarket economyhad barely begun under the new Croatian Government when war broke out in 1991. As a result of the war, the economic infrastructure sustained massive damage, particularly the revenue-rich tourism industry. From 1989 to 1993, the GDP fell 40.5%. The Croatian state still controls a significant part of the economy, with government expenditures accounting for as much as 40% of GDP.cite webhttp://m.state.gov/md3166.htmBackground Note: Croatia[[United States Department of State]]4 December 2008A backlogged judiciary system, combined with inefficientpublic administration, especially on issues of land ownership and corruption, are particular concerns. In 2011 the country has been ranked 66th byTransparency Internationalwith aCorruption Perceptions Indexof 4.0.cite webhttp://www.guardian.co.uk/news/datablog/2011/dec/01/corruption-index-2011-transparency-internationalCorruption index 2011 from Transparency International: find out how countries compare[[guardian.co.uk]]21 June 20121 December 2011Simon RogersClaire ProvostIn June 2013, the national debt stood at 59.5% of the nation's GDP.cite webhttp://countryeconomy.com/national-debt/croatiaCroatia National Debt on Country Economycountryeconomy.com3 December 2013
article.heading: Tourism
article.paragraph: mainTourism in Croatiamultiple imageright vertical 220 Papaya club @ Zrche beach day.jpg Papaya club on Zrće beach on Pag. Golden_Cape.jpg [[Zlatni Rat]] beach on [[Brač]] Island, one of foremost spots of [[tourism in Croatia]]. Tourism in CroatiaTourismdominates the Croatian service sector and accounts for up to 20% of Croatian GDP. Annual tourist industry income for 2011 was estimated at 6.61 billion. Its positive effects are felt throughout the economy of Croatia in terms of increased business volume observed in retail business, processing industry orders and summer seasonal employment. The industry is considered an export business, because it significantly reduces the country's external trade imbalance.cite newsVjesnikhttp://www.vjesnik.hr/Article.aspx?ID14 June 2012yeshttp://www.webcitation.org/68PYhbBryCroatianIako čini gotovo petinu BDP-a, i dalje niskoprofitabilna grana domaće privredeEven though it comprises nearly a fifth of the GDP, it is still a low-profit branch of the national economyTomislav PiliDavor Verković1 October 201120 October 2011Since the conclusion of the Croatian War of Independence, the tourist industry has grown rapidly, recording a fourfold rise in tourist numbers, with more than 10 million tourists each year.The most numerous are tourists fromGermany, Slovenia, Austria and theCzech Republicas well as Croatia itself. Length of a tourist stay in Croatia averages 4.9 days.cite web[[T-Hrvatski Telekom]]t-portal.hrCroatianhttp://www.tportal.hr/biznis/gospodarstvo/148403/Turisticki-prihod-porast-ce-prvi-put-nakon-2008.html14 September 2011Turistički prihod porast će prvi put nakon 2008.Tourist income to rise for the first time since 200821 October 2011

The bulk of the tourist industry is concentrated along the Adriatic Sea coast.Opatijawas the first holiday resort since the middle of the 19th century. By the 1890s, it became one of the most significant European health resorts.cite webOpatija Tourist Boardhttp://www.opatija-tourism.hr/en/Home.aspx?PageIDHistory of Opatija21 October 2011Later a large number of resorts sprang up along the coast and numerous islands, offering services ranging frommass tourismto catering and various niche markets, the most significant beingnautical tourism, as there are numerous marinas with more than 16 thousand berths,cultural tourismrelying on appeal of medieval coastal cities and numerous cultural events taking place during the summer. Inland areas offer mountain resorts,agrotourismandspas. Zagreb is also a significant tourist destination, rivalling major coastal cities and resorts.cite web[[Croatian National Tourist Board]]http://croatia.hr/en-GB/Activities-and-attractionsActivities and attractions21 October 2011

Croatia has unpolluted marine areas reflected through numerous nature reserves and 116Blue Flag beaches.cite webhttp://www.blueflag.org/Menu/Awarded+sites/2011/Northern+Hemisphere/CroatiaCroatia21 October 2011[[Foundation for Environmental Education]]Croatia is ranked as the 18th most popular tourist destination in the world.cite webhttp://www.unwto.org/facts/eng/pdf/barometer/UNWTO_Barom07_3_en.pdfUNWTO World Tourism BarometerOctober 200723 April 2008About 15% of these visitors (over one million per year) are involved withnaturism, an industry for which Croatia is world famous. It was also the first European country to develop commercial naturist resorts.cite webhttp://www.euro-poi.com/croatian-highlights-croatia-278.htmlCroatian highlights, CroatiaEuro-poi.com26 March 2013
article.heading: Infrastructure

template.arg: The [[A7 (Croatia)|A7]], a part of Croatia's [[Highways in Croatia|motorway network]].
The [[Port of Rijeka]], the largest Croatian seaport.

article.paragraph: The highlight of Croatia's recentinfrastructuredevelopments is its rapidly developedMotorways in Croatiamotorway network, largely built in the late 1990s and especially in the 2000s (decade). By September 2011, Croatia had completed more thanconvert1100kmoffof motorways, connecting Zagreb to most other regions and following variousInternational E-road networkEuropean routesand fourPan-European corridors.cite journal[[University of Rijeka|University of Rijeka, Faculty of Maritime Studies]]http://hrcak.srce.hr/file/6570The integration of the Republic of Croatia into the Pan-European transport corridor networkTanja Poletan JugovićPomorstvo20149–6511 April 200614 October 2010cite newsNarodne NovineCroatianhttp://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/2007_07_77_2443.htmlOdluka o razvrstavanju javnih cesta u autocesteDecision on classification of public roads as motorways25 July 200718 October 2010cite newsNarodne NovineCroatianhttp://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/2009_01_13_296.htmlOdluka o izmjenama i dopunama odluke o razvrstavanju javnih cesta u autocesteDecision on amendments and additions to the Decision on classification of public roads as motorways30 January 200918 October 2010The busiest motorways are theA1 (Croatia)A1, connecting Zagreb to Split and theA3 (Croatia)A3, passing eastwest through northwest Croatia and Slavonia.cite web[[Hrvatske ceste]]http://www.hrvatske-ceste.hr/WEB%20-%20Legislativa/brojenje-prometa/CroDig2009.pdfTraffic counting on the roadways of Croatia in 2009 – digestPDF1 May 2010A widespread network ofstate roads in Croatiaacts as motorwayFeeder line (network)feeder roadswhile connecting all major settlements in the country. The high quality and safety levels of the Croatian motorway network were tested and confirmed by several EuroTAP and EuroTest programs.cite webhttp://www.eurotestmobility.com/news.php?itemEuroTestEurotestmobility.com3 January 2009cite webhttp://www.javno.com/en/croatia/clanak.php?idBrinje Tunnel Best European TunnelJavno.com3 January 2009

Croatia has anList of railways in Croatiaextensive rail networkspanningconvert2722kmoff, includingconvert985kmoffof electrified railways andconvert254kmoffof double track railways.The most significant railways in Croatia are found within the Pan-European transport corridors Vb and X connecting Rijeka to Budapest and Ljubljana to Belgrade, both via Zagreb.All rail services are operated byCroatian Railways.cite newsVjesnikSkuplje korištenje pruga uništava HŽMore Expensive Railway Fees Ruin Croatian RailwaysCroatian10 May 2011Tomislav Pilihttp://www.vjesnik.hr/Article.aspx?ID14 June 2012yeshttp://www.webcitation.org/68PYpf0Jp26 October 2011

There areinternational airportsinZagreb International AirportZagreb,Zadar AirportZadar,Split AirportSplit,Dubrovnik AirportDubrovnik,Rijeka AirportRijeka,Osijek AirportOsijekandPula AirportPula.cite web[[Ministry of the Sea, Transport and Infrastructure (Croatia)]]http://www.mppi.hr/default.aspx?idAir transport10 October 2011As of January 2011, Croatia complies withInternational Civil Aviation Organizationaviation safety standards and theFederal Aviation Administrationupgraded it to Category 1 rating.cite webhttp://www.faa.gov/news/press_releases/news_story.cfm?newsIdFAA Raises Safety Rating for Croatia[[Federal Aviation Administration]]26 January 201127 January 2011

The busiest cargoseaportin Croatia is thePort of Rijekaand the busiest passenger ports arePort of SplitSplitand Zadar.cite webWorld BankCroatianRiječka luka –jadranski "prolaz" prema EuropiThe Port of Rijeka – Adriatic "gateway" to Europe3 March 200613 October 2011http://go.worldbank.org/V9N60RX7L0cite webMinistry of the Sea, Transport and Infrastructure (Croatia)http://www.mppi.hr/default.aspx?idLukePortsCroatian24 August 2011In addition to those, a large number of minor ports serve an extensive system of ferries connecting numerous islands and coastal cities in addition to ferry lines to several cities in Italy.cite webAgencija za obalni linijski pomorski promethttp://www.agencija-zolpp.hr/Brodskelinije/tabid/1267/Default.aspxCroatianPlovidbeni red za 2011. godinuSailing Schedule for Year 201127 August 2011The largest river port is Vukovar, located on the Danube, representing the nation's outlet to the Pan-European transport corridor VII.cite webMinistry of the Sea, Transport and Infrastructure (Croatia)http://www.mppi.hr/default.aspx?idPlovni putoviNavigable routesCroatian10 September 2011

There areconvert610kmoffof crude oil pipelines in Croatia, connecting the Port of Rijeka oil terminal with refineries in Rijeka and Sisak, as well as several transhipment terminals. The system has a capacity of 20 million tonnes per year.cite web[[Jadranski naftovod]]http://www.janaf.hr/index.php?optionThe JANAF system8 October 2011The natural gas transportation system comprisesconvert2113kmoffof trunk and regional natural gas pipelines, and more than 300 associated structures, connecting production rigs, the Okoli natural gas storage facility, 27 end-users and 37 distribution systems.cite web[[Plinacro]]http://www.plinacro.hr/default.aspx?idTransportni sustavTransport systemCroatian8 October 2011

Croatian production of energy sources covers 85% of nationwide natural gas demand and 19% of oil demand. In 2008, 47.6% of Croatia's primary energy production structure comprised use of natural gas (47.7%), crude oil (18.0%), fuel wood (8.4%), hydro power (25.4%) and other renewable energy sources (0.5%). In 2009, net total electrical power production in Croatia reached 12,725 GWh and Croatia imported 28.5% of its electric power energy needs.The bulk of Croatian imports are supplied by theKrko Nuclear Power Plant, 50% owned byHrvatska elektroprivreda, providing 15% of Croatia's electricity.cite webEU Businesshttp://www.eubusiness.com/news-eu/japan-disaster.9bcCroatia, Slovenia's nuclear plant safe: Croatian president28 March 20118 October 2011
article.heading: Demographics
article.paragraph: MainDemographics of CroatiaReligion in CroatiaCroatsFile:Croatian censuses 1857-2011.gifthumbleftupright=1.5Population of Croatia (in thousands) from 18572011.With its population of 4.28 million in 2011, CroatiaList of countries by populationranks 125th by populationin the world.ItsList of sovereign states and dependent territories by population densitypopulation densitystands at 75.9 inhabitants per square kilometre.
